Despite the futile efforts of ill will, these societies will exert a significant <tei-pb n="31" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/> influence on this important question, and we believe that the unfortunate blacks will soon experience its beneficial effects.</tei-p>
         </tei-div>
         <tei-div data-origname="div">
            <tei-head data-origname="head">ENGLAND.</tei-head>
            <tei-head data-origname="head">LONDON.</tei-head>
            <tei-head data-origname="head">BANQUET IN HONOR OF THE ABOLITION OF SLAVERY.</tei-head>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">On August 1, a public banquet was held at the Freemasons' Tavern to celebrate the abolition of slavery, which took effect that day throughout the entire extent of Great Britain's colonial possessions. The <tei-persName ref="#Mul" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Right Honorable Lord Earl Mulgrave</tei-persName> presided. Shortly after half-past six, 132 people took their seats at the table.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Among those present were noted figures such as <tei-persName ref="#SR" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Secretary Rice</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#MOR" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Viscount Morpeth</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#LUS" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Dr. Lushington</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#HV" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Sir H. Varney</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#WH" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Whitmore</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#OC" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. O'Connel</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#WA" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. H. G. Ward</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#BUC" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. T.-S. Buckingham</tei-persName>, all members of Parliament, along with several others who had played an active role in the great question of the emancipation of the negroes, which is now happily resolved.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">A large number of men of color from the West Indies also attended the banquet; their presence, as might be expected, only added to the significance of the gathering. Indeed, the eloquent and moving speech delivered by one of them, <tei-persName ref="#LEC" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Lecesne</tei-persName>, during the evening provided further and convincing proof that the gifts of intellect are equally shared among all people, regardless of their homeland or color, and that not only necessity but justice demanded that English legislation enact this great measure, by which our black brothers in the colonies have been restored to freedom through both policy and morality.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">At the conclusion of the dinner, the noble president proposed a toast to the king’s health, observing that the great event they were celebrating </tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">(1) Private Lord Chancellor and Cabinet Member <tei-pb n="32" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/> would, in future centuries, occupy the most glorious page in the history of this monarch’s life and reign. (Applause.)</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">After this toast, <tei-persName ref="#BUX" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Buxton</tei-persName> stood and proposed another, which, he said, could not fail to win universal approval: "To the health of the newly emancipated peoples of the colonies!" (Resounding cheers.) However, before delivering this toast, he wished to address a few questions to the last governor of Jamaica regarding the past and present state of that island. He said he desired an answer to these questions to demonstrate that the defenders of anti-slavery were incapable of exaggeration or misrepresentation of facts.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Earl Mulgrave rose amidst thunderous applause. He responded that he would gladly provide details of what he had observed during his tenure as governor of <tei-placeName ref="#JA" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Jamaica</tei-placeName>: "There are some cases to which I can scarcely think back without sorrowful memories and of which I will speak only lightly, for all past grievances must be forgotten, at least as much as present circumstances allow, and especially on an occasion like this, when freeborn Englishmen are gathered to celebrate the finest day in their history.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Had circumstances permitted, I would have wished to spend this memorable day in Jamaica. What joy I would have felt at seeing thousands of happy and jubilant faces greeting its dawn! It was the day of the birth of their freedom." (Cheers.) "Had my health allowed, I would have sacrificed everything to be among them." (Cheers.)</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">"My esteemed friend has asked me to provide an account of what I saw in Jamaica, and I will do my best to oblige."</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">After asking the assembly to excuse the brevity of his remarks, he continued: "I base my opinion on my personal interactions with the negroes themselves. The defenders of the inhumane system of slavery have spoken much about the improvement in the condition of these unfortunate beings over the past few years. It is my duty to say that I consider their claims greatly exaggerated. Atrocities were committed up until the very moment the bill for the emancipation of the slaves was passed; these atrocities could not have been prevented or halted by any partial measures."</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">"If this <tei-pb n="33" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/> great measure had not been adopted, a horrible upheaval would inevitably have followed. Upon my arrival in Jamaica, I found the island in the most terrible confusion; great discontent prevailed among the blacks due to their frustrated hopes and the uncertainty surrounding their freedom. However, I am happy to say that by the end of my tenure as governor of the island, significant improvements had taken place.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Seven months ago, I toured the island. During this journey, I addressed 50,000 blacks and clearly and extensively explained to them the great change they were about to experience. My heart leapt with joy at the extraordinary attention they gave to my words. I will never forget the joy shining on their faces during these occasions. I told them that corporal punishments would no longer be inflicted; that they and their children would henceforth be free, and that education would be extended to all so they could better enjoy the benefits of liberty.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Then, as now, I was deeply convinced that slavery was repugnant to every moral and religious sentiment; it had to be either abolished entirely or left as it was—half-measures would not suffice. My conviction was reinforced by the farewell words of my noble predecessor, the Duke of Manchester, who declared that the island’s resources would not be fully developed until slavery was completely eradicated.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Such were the degrading effects of slavery, not only on the minds of the enslaved but also on those of the masters, that examples can be cited where women inflicted the most terrible tortures on their own sex; similar crimes were committed by monsters in human form when enslaved women refused to submit to their brutal passions.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">The blacks will no longer be treated like beasts of burden; they will henceforth enjoy the privileges of free men. I am convinced, based on what I have seen and learned, that they will one day become good and useful subjects; and I know, beyond a shadow of a doubt, that the mind of the black person is fully capable of receiving moral and religious instruction."</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">The noble lord concluded his speech by wishing a long life to the newly emancipated slaves.</tei-p>
               <tei-pb n="34" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Mr. Buxton, after noting that from this day forward slavery would be entirely abolished and that the black man, who until now had been regarded as an article of commerce, would henceforth enjoy the privileges of a British subject, said that once the energy of the black man had been fully developed in a state of liberty, his abilities would in every way equal those of the whites. "And who knows," he continued, "if in a few years the character of the black man will not be so elevated as to rival the proudest and most arrogant among those who have so long despised him?"</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Mr. Spring-Rice, Secretary of the Colonies, then rose and expressed his satisfaction at being present for the celebration of the great triumph that the friends of humanity had just achieved in favor of the so greatly degraded blacks. "I thank Providence," he continued, "for having crowned their efforts, and seeing myself surrounded by men who, amidst both favorable and unfavorable reports, worked so long to accomplish this great and glorious project, I confess that I am proud to have been associated with them. I hope the country will do justice to the great and excellent men, members of Her Majesty's government, who have so powerfully contributed to the emancipation of the slaves. I cannot forget that these were the same men who, in 1806, introduced the bill for the abolition of the slave trade. The moral and religious education of the blacks must now be the government’s primary consideration, and it will devote its full attention to it."</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">The honorable speaker, concluding by announcing that no effort on his part would be spared in working toward the prosperity of the colonies, proposed this toast: "To the political and social prosperity of the colonies!"</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Mr. Lecesne, the man of color previously mentioned, expressed his thanks, in his own name and that of the black population of the colonies, to Her Majesty’s government, which, with the assistance of the friends of the blacks in this country, had accomplished such a glorious change. He spoke of the administration of the noble president as governor of Jamaica in the highest terms and observed that the tranquility now reigning in Jamaica was primarily due to the gentle yet firm and judicious manner in which the noble earl had conducted himself during his <tei-pb n="35" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/> tenure on the island.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">He concluded by proposing a toast to the health of the noble president. The president, in thanking him, alluded to the eloquence and good taste Mr. Lecesne had demonstrated in his speech.</tei-p>

            <tei-head data-origname="head">ORGANIZATION OF THE COLONY OF ALGIERS.</tei-head>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">The <tei-bibl type="periodical" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type"><tei-title ref="#MU" data-origname="title" data-origatts="ref">Moniteur</tei-title></tei-bibl> of August 15 publishes several ordinances concerning our possessions in North Africa.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">The first ordinance, dated July 27, stipulates that the general command and high administration of the French possessions in North Africa (the former Regency of <tei-placeName ref="#Alg" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Algiers</tei-placeName>) are entrusted to a governor-general. He exercises his powers under the orders and direction of the Minister of War.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">A general officer commanding the troops, a civil intendant, a general officer commanding the navy, a public prosecutor, a military intendant, and a director of finances are responsible for the various civil and military services under the orders of the governor-general and within the scope of their respective duties.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">The governor-general is assisted by a council composed of the officials just mentioned. Depending on the nature of the matters submitted to the council, the governor-general invites the heads of specialized civil or military services relevant to the discussions. These individuals have a consultative voice.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Until further orders are given, the French possessions in North Africa will be governed by royal ordinances. The governor-general prepares, in council, the draft ordinances required by the situation in the country and transmits them to the Minister of War. In extraordinary and urgent cases, he may provisionally render the provisions of these drafts enforceable by decree.</tei-p>
               <tei-pb n="36" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">A second ordinance, also dated July 27, appoints <tei-persName ref="#DRO" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">M. the Lieutenant-General Drouet, Count d'Erlon, Governor-General</tei-persName>. Then comes the ordinance on justice, dated August 10. There will be courts of first instance in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Algiers</tei-placeName>, in <tei-placeName ref="#BON" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Bone</tei-placeName>, and in <tei-placeName ref="#OR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Oran</tei-placeName>, a commercial court, and a superior court in Algiers. Muslim assessors are attached to the courts of first instance in Algiers, Bone, and Oran. Indigenous courts are maintained. There will be Jewish courts wherever needed.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">By a fourth ordinance, dated August 12, <tei-persName ref="#LEP" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Lepasquier</tei-persName>, Prefect of Finistère, is appointed Civil Intendant of the French possessions in North Africa, replacing <tei-persName ref="#GDB" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">M. Genty de Bussy</tei-persName>.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">By another ordinance of August 12, <tei-persName ref="#LA" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Laurence</tei-persName>, Deputy, is appointed Special Commissioner of Justice. A final ordinance, also of August 12, appoints <tei-persName ref="#BDB" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Rear Admiral Botherel de la Bretonnière Commander of the Navy</tei-persName> in the African possessions. He will reside in Algiers.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">By ordinance of August 25 have been appointed: President of the Superior Court of Algiers, <tei-persName ref="#FIL" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">M. Filhon</tei-persName>, Advocate General at the Royal Court of <tei-placeName ref="#BAS" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Bastia</tei-placeName>; Judges in the French possessions of North Africa, Messrs. <tei-persName ref="#BDM" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Bonnet des Maisons</tei-persName>, currently judge in the said possessions; <tei-persName ref="#CLM" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Cornisset-la-Mathe</tei-persName>, idem ; <tei-persName ref="#SAL" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Salles, Investigating Judge at the Civil Court of Lourdes</tei-persName>; <tei-persName ref="#PD" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Ponton-Damécourt (Louis)</tei-persName>, former Public Prosecutor; <tei-persName ref="#SOL" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Solvet, Deputy Public Prosecutor at the Civil Court of Soissons</tei-persName>; <tei-persName ref="#GI" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Giaccobi, Deputy Public Prosecutor at the Civil Court of Quimper</tei-persName>; <tei-persName ref="#VE" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Verdun, Deputy Public Prosecutor at the Civil Court of Vienne;</tei-persName>; Substitute Judges: Messrs. <tei-persName ref="#GAU" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Gaurans, Lawyer in Toulouse</tei-persName>, et <tei-persName ref="#GE" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Germain, Lawyer in Saint-Gaudens</tei-persName>. First Deputy Public Prosecutor to the King in Algiers: <tei-persName ref="#LOY" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Loyson, Public Prosecutor at the Civil Court of Colmar</tei-persName>. Deputies to the Public Prosecutor General to the King in Algiers: Messrs. <tei-persName ref="#DA" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Daverton, former Public Prosecutor at the Civil Court of Melle</tei-persName>; <tei-persName ref="#REL" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Renaud Lebon, Lawyer in Paris</tei-persName>; and <tei-persName ref="#FL" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Fleury, Deputy Public Prosecutor at the Civil Court of Castellane</tei-persName>.</tei-p>

            <tei-p data-origname="p">MISCELLANEOUS NEWS.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">We are informed that <tei-persName ref="#CT" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Charles Télèphe</tei-persName>, an officer of the National Guard of Martinique, currently in <tei-placeName ref="#Par" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Paris</tei-placeName>, has just written a letter to the Minister of the Navy and Colonies to enlighten the minister on the dreadful <tei-rs type="event" data-origname="rs" data-origatts="type">affair of Grand'Anse</tei-rs>. It is known that Mr. Télèphe played a role in this matter: in his capacity as an officer of the National Guard, he was entrusted with the confidence of the governor, in a moment when there was concern about the position the majority of men of color would take in the presence of their armed brethren, who, like the whites, had also entrenched themselves in the camp of Fond-Capot. Mr. Télèphe was the bearer of amnesty proposals for the men of color. It is said that in his letter, Mr. Télèphe explains all these particulars to the minister. We can only applaud the sense of justice and patriotism that prompted this officer to write this letter.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">- During a meeting of the founders of the <tei-orgName ref="#SAE" data-origname="orgName" data-origatts="ref">Society for the Abolition of Slavery</tei-orgName>, held on August 15, the members present resolved to offer the presidency of the Society to the <tei-persName ref="#BRO" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Duke of Broglie</tei-persName>, whose eloquent speeches in the Chamber of Peers on the slave trade are honorable precedents and valuable assurances. Messrs. <tei-persName ref="#PAS" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Passy</tei-persName> and <tei-persName ref="#OB" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Odilon-Barrot</tei-persName> were appointed vice-presidents, and Messrs. <tei-persName ref="#AD" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Delaborde</tei-persName> and <tei-persName ref="#FI" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Isambert</tei-persName> were named secretaries. Mr. Passy was tasked with drafting the program of the Society’s objectives, while Mr. Isambert will prepare a study on the first modifications needed in colonial legislation regarding enslaved people. Mr. Gaëtan de Larochefoucauld has agreed to draft an analysis of the work of the Society for Christian Morality in relation to the abolition of slavery.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">A letter from Mr. Gaëtan de Larochefoucauld, communicated to us by Mr. Delaborde, secretary of the Society for the Abolition of Slavery, announces that several Peers of France and a large number of Deputies have expressed their desire to join this Society; among the names, we note Admiral Verhuell, known for his excellent speech in the Chamber of Peers on the slave trade.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">- The inhabitants of Senegal, in recognition of the good services <tei-pb n="38" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/> rendered to them in the past by Baron Roger, former governor of that colony and now a member of the Chamber of Deputies, have sent him an African pirogue made from a single tree trunk.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">- Have been admitted as doctor-physicians at the Faculty of Medicine in Paris, the men of color whose names follow: <tei-persName ref="#ACL" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Antoine Clavier</tei-persName>, of Martinique.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName ref="#SALE" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Salesse</tei-persName>, of <tei-placeName ref="#IM" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Mauritius</tei-placeName>.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName ref="#MER" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Merlet</tei-persName>, of <tei-placeName ref="#HT" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Haiti</tei-placeName>.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName ref="#EC" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Eugène Clavier</tei-persName> has been admitted as a lawyer in <tei-placeName ref="#RE" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Rennes</tei-placeName>.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">- <tei-persName ref="#CB" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">M. Bissette</tei-persName> was summoned to the correctional police court by <tei-persName ref="#ART" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Artaud</tei-persName>, on account of a <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Letter to <tei-persName ref="#CIC" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Cicéron</tei-persName>, lawyer in Martinique</tei-emph>; in this letter, Mr. Artaud perceived an act of defamation against him. The court, without regard for Mr. Artaud’s conclusions, sentenced Mr. Bissette to a fine of 25 francs. We will report on this trial in our next issue. It is said that <tei-persName ref="#ANog" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Arsène Nogues, Attorney General in Martinique</tei-persName>, is striving with all his might to earn the hand of a young Creole woman, the daughter of a wealthy white planter of the colony. Has Mr. Arsène Nogues earned his spurs with the judgment of condemnation he has just obtained from the court in Martinique? We are assured that the delegates of the Martinican aristocracy are petitioning the Minister of the Navy and Colonies for the decoration of officer of the Legion of Honor for Mr. Arsène Nogues. Mr. Arsène Nogues had already been decorated with the Legion of Honor shortly after the execution of the twenty-four slaves sentenced to death in 1831. After the condemnation in the case of the deportees from Martinique in 1824, <tei-persName ref="#RL" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">RICHARD-LUCY</tei-persName>, then Attorney General, came to France, petitioned the Ministry of the Navy, and very easily obtained the decoration of the Legion of Honor. It is known that RICHARD Lucy had enforced the sentence of condemnation to perpetual <tei-pb n="39" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/> galley service in defiance of the appeal in cassation that had been filed by the condemned.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">We believe, from a reliable source, that the three magistrates who presided over the Grand'Anse affair, <tei-persName ref="#PER" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Perrinelle</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#LePell" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Lepelletier-Duclary</tei-persName> as well as RICHARD-LUCY, are very shortly to arrive in France.</tei-p>

         <tei-div data-origname="div">
            <tei-head data-origname="head">FRENCH COLONIES.</tei-head>
            <tei-head data-origname="head">MARTINIQUE.</tei-head>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">We are informed from <tei-placeName ref="#StP" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Saint-Pierre</tei-placeName>:</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">"........ Our unfortunate condemned have filed appeals in cassation. Here you have the list of those condemned to death. It is said that the ruling is to be printed, which I will be sure to send to you.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Truly, my dear friend, for a month we have been wearied by the sight, morning and evening, of a procession of men, chained or handcuffed two by two, and bound on top of that, escorted by 60 to 80 royal gendarmes with rifles and around 200 soldiers.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">I forgot to tell you that our unfortunate brothers did not dare speak, during their interrogation, about <tei-placeName ref="#CBO" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">camp Bonafond</tei-placeName>'s white flag'.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">It is said that <tei-persName ref="#DESL" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Deslix</tei-persName>, a lawyer from <tei-placeName ref="#FoR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Fort-Royal</tei-placeName>, after demanding 22 quadruples of Spain from eight unfortunates to defend them, advised these poor ignorant men not to mention this circumstance, under the pretext that it might prejudice the judges against them. But would you believe it? This same Deslix, after having charged so dearly, did not even wait for the ruling to file the appeal for his unfortunate clients in case of condemnation, and left for Fort-Royal yesterday before the judgment was pronounced.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">What will your European lawyers say of such conduct? His defense is so thoroughly colonial that he sought, and easily obtained, permission to have it printed in the official journal, where it appeared last Sunday, June 29, while they feared to allow the publication of the debates. Admirable distributive justice!" <tei-persName ref="#BART" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Barthel</tei-persName> alone spoke boldly about the white flag of the <tei-pb n="40" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/> Bonafond camp. <tei-persName ref="#PER" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Perrinelle</tei-persName> said to him: "You are mistaken; it was a tablecloth with a wine stain that had been placed in the sun."</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">"Mr. President," Barthel replied, "one does not place a tablecloth at the end of a bamboo over twenty feet long to dry in the sun."</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">We are working on the appeal for our unfortunate friends. No, it shall not be said that so many victims are left to be led to the scaffold. France will protect us from the terror of the whites.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Throughout this affair, Barthel and <tei-persName ref="#SAM" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Samuel</tei-persName> have conducted themselves admirably; they responded with dignity and firmness. <tei-persName ref="#LTelem" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Léonce</tei-persName>, however, allowed himself to be intimidated......</tei-p>
         </tei-div>
         <tei-div data-origname="div">
            <tei-head data-origname="head">GUADELOUPE. </tei-head>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">The individuals named <tei-persName ref="#MDP" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Marianne</tei-persName> and <tei-persName ref="#SFDP" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Sébastiano-Francisco de Paula</tei-persName>, on the night of June 11, murdered the unfortunate <tei-persName ref="#FV" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Francisque Vaille</tei-persName>, master of the port, at Pointe-à-Pitre.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Marianne had been working for quite some time on the barges in the city and was considered to be an intimate friend of Vaille; Vaille himself even referred to him as his brother. Vaille had gone fishing on June 11, at nine o’clock in the evening, with Marianne and Sébastiano-Francisco de Paula. The next day, the latter two returned alone and, going to Vaille’s residence, ordered his servant, in his name, to prepare an excellent dinner for them and for her master, who they claimed had stayed behind at <tei-placeName ref="#IAC" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Île à Cochon</tei-placeName>.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">During the servant’s absence, they reportedly broke open Vaille’s trunks and stole several jewels, seven silver utensils, and a sum of twelve to fifteen hundred francs. They even took Vaille’s uniform insignias, his documents, and his commission as port master. They had already secured passage aboard the schooner <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Le Condor</tei-emph>, which departed the next day for <tei-placeName ref="#StT" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Saint Thomas</tei-placeName>, and, by a stroke of fatality, no one raised concern about Vaille’s disappearance until his murderers were already beyond the reach of the law.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">It was not until June 14 that Vaille’s body was found near <tei-placeName ref="#MAS" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Morne à Savon</tei-placeName>, carried there by the currents. His body was riddled with dagger wounds; there were wounds on his back, his abdomen, and his head, with three directed at his heart. More than fifteen wounds were counted. After his death, Vaille was thrown into the sea, his neck tied with a rope weighted down with stones.</tei-p>
               <tei-pb n="41" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/>
         </tei-div>
         <tei-div data-origname="div">
            <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#GF" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">GUIANA</tei-placeName></tei-head>
            <tei-p data-origname="p"> We are informed from <tei-placeName ref="#Cay" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Cayenne</tei-placeName>:</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">..... We are here under the unfortunate influence of an aristocratic clique that relentlessly persecutes all independent men who have taken seriously the modifications brought by the new law to our old colonial legislation, which these gentlemen of the clique are determined to maintain at all costs.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName ref="#PERS" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Persegol</tei-persName> is one such man; as a result, this honorable magistrate has been forced to leave a post in which, for nearly ten years of service, he has always distinguished himself by his impartiality. The Minister of the Navy, by provoking M. Persegol's resignation, has undoubtedly acted at the instigation of some high-ranking officials who oppose the new law.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">We hope that the Minister of the Navy, despite the ill spirit of the colony's chief presently in <tei-placeName ref="#Par" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Paris</tei-placeName>, will return M. Persegol to Cayenne. We cannot understand, truly, why this magistrate’s conduct has been called into question. But, I repeat, there is hope here that justice will be served and that he will be sent back among us.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Foolishness and prejudice reign here as sovereigns: merely having respect for fairness and wanting justice to be equal for all, whether in protection or in punishment, is enough to become the target of the animosity of the proud and servile aristocrats who dominate us.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">In Paris, one cannot conceive of the illiberal absurdity of our officials of all ranks, most of whom are as small-minded as they are petty. In the atmosphere of liberty in which you live, I doubt you could believe in such excesses of brutishness. It goes so far that we have seen—believe me, do not laugh in disbelief but rather feel indignation or laugh bitterly with contempt—yes, we have seen a civil registry officer refuse to record the revered names of <tei-persName ref="#TRA" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Tracy</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#AD" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Delaborde</tei-persName>,<tei-persName ref="#FI" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Isambert</tei-persName>,<tei-persName ref="#ES" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Salverte</tei-persName>,<tei-persName ref="#LdV" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Villevêque</tei-persName> etc., which men of color wished to give to their children as a token of their deep gratitude for these honorable defenders of their liberty. Is it possible to imagine anything like it? Language, does it not, lacks the words to describe such ineptitude combined with such little respect <tei-pb n="42" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/> for common rights?</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">It is, however, by such actions of this kind that our authorities often distinguish themselves. Poor civilization of ours! In this affair, the ridiculous outweighs the barbaric; fortunate when barbarity does not outweigh the ridiculous!.....</tei-p>
         </tei-div>
         <tei-div data-origname="div">
            <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#SEN" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">SENEGAL</tei-placeName></tei-head>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">The most recent dispatches are dated June 29. They report that an envoy from the chief of the Trarza Moors arrived in <tei-placeName ref="#STLO" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Saint-Louis</tei-placeName> on June 24 to negotiate peace; however, failing to reach an agreement with the Governor of Senegal on the terms of the treaty to be concluded, the envoy returned to <tei-persName ref="#MEH" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">King Mohamed-el-Habib</tei-persName> to inform him of the conditions imposed. Hostilities had, moreover, ceased on both the right and left banks of the river.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">It was generally believed in Saint-Louis that the destitution in which the Trarza Moors found themselves, as a result of the war disrupting their commercial relations with Senegal, would soon compel them to seek peace under the terms they had so far rejected.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">By a ruling of April 9, 1854, the appellate council of Senegal and its dependencies, sitting in Saint-Louis, declared guilty of the crime of trafficking blacks in the Salum River, a dependency of Senegal, using the schooner <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Laguila de Oro</tei-emph>, and sentenced, under Articles 5, 4, and 5 of the law of March 4, 1851, concerning the suppression of the slave trade, and Articles 21, 22, and 66 of the Penal Code, as follows:  <tei-persName ref="#DP" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Domingo Pratz</tei-persName> and <tei-persName ref="#TCA" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Théodore Canot</tei-persName> to five years of forced labor; <tei-persName ref="#FPC" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Francisco and Paula Coll</tei-persName> et <tei-persName ref="#MR" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Manuel Rodriguez</tei-persName> to five years of solitary confinement, and all four to public exposure in the pillory for one hour; <tei-persName ref="#BOLI" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Barthélemy Olivier</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#JMM" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">José-Maria Martorel</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#LPA" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Louis Palou</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#JH" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">José Hubedas</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#ATO" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Andrès Torres</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#JF" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Juan Frédérick</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#JZ" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Juan Zamora</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#ABE" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Antonio Berga</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#JB" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Jayme Bisbal</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#JBG" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Jean-Baptiste Grive</tei-persName> and <tei-persName ref="#AGA" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Antoine Galone</tei-persName> to one year of imprisonment; and all together to the costs of the proceedings payable to the state.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">The same ruling ordered the confiscation and sale, by the appropriate authority, of the schooner <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Laguila de Oro</tei-emph>.</tei-p>
         </tei-div>
         <tei-div data-origname="div">
            <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#Alg" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">ALGIERS</tei-placeName></tei-head>
            <tei-p data-origname="p"> Work continues actively. The number of ill is much lower than in previous years. Our relations <tei-pb n="44" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/> with the Arabs are currently not hostile, but they are far from being as amicable and secure as was claimed in official reports. However, while some tribes show hostility, there is not the slightest sign of a general conflagration, and our establishments will have nothing to fear as long as they face only a few partial attacks. Some tribes having attempted to cut our communications in the territory of the Ouled-Boasis, that people and a few neighboring groups unexpectedly fell upon the hostile tribes and routed them completely.</tei-p>
         </tei-div>
         <tei-div data-origname="div">
            <tei-head data-origname="head">FOREIGN COLONIES.</tei-head>
            <tei-head data-origname="head">MAURITIUS.</tei-head>
            <tei-p data-origname="p"> The <tei-bibl type="periodical" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type"><tei-title ref="#LC" data-origname="title" data-origatts="ref">le Cernéen</tei-title></tei-bibl> contains the following article on the colonies: Colonial questions relate to two entirely distinct viewpoints, whether considered in terms of the emancipation of the blacks—a specifically English question that will soon become that of all civilized nations—or in terms of material aspects such as production, economy, and commercial development.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">The emancipation of the blacks is a question of principle; and from the day the slave trade was abolished and rejected, the principle was established. Indeed, must not one who advocates slavery, if consistent, also advocate the slave trade? No longer does one say, as <tei-persName ref="#MON" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. de Montvéran</tei-persName> remarks, the abolition of slavery; instead, one says the emancipation of the blacks, and this modesty in terms heralds the resolution of the question. It is a powerful fact to present to those who deny the progress of civilization, that this complete shift in public opinion now regards as unjust and unnecessary what, a century ago, was seen as the rightful and necessary practice of the black slave trade.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-placeName ref="#ANG" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">England</tei-placeName>, now at the forefront of this philanthropic movement, was indeed the first to engage in the slave trade on the western coast of Africa. <tei-persName ref="#QEI" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Queen Elisabeth</tei-persName>, along with her entire court, held shares in this infamous trade, which was continued by <tei-persName ref="#KJI" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">James I</tei-persName> and <tei-persName ref="#KCI" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Charles I</tei-persName>. Since 1670, approximately five million blacks have been imported into the West Indies and the American <tei-pb n="45" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/> continent north of the equator. Defying the ordinary laws of population, 4,555,220 blacks and 2,458,000 mulattoes, mestizos, and mixed-blood individuals now represent this vast stock. South of the equator, two million Brazilian blacks perhaps represent even greater misfortune.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">The six French colonies count 270,000 slaves, whom the colonists estimate at 1,500 francs each; the Spanish colonies of <tei-placeName ref="#CUB" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Cuba</tei-placeName> et de<tei-placeName ref="#PR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Puerto-Rico</tei-placeName> have 320,000 slaves, valued at approximately 1,000 francs each; the eighteen English colonies in the <tei-placeName ref="#GdM" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">gulf of Mexico</tei-placeName> and the <tei-placeName ref="#IM" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Isle of France (Mauritius)</tei-placeName> have 693,200 slaves, valued at 1,500 francs each. This, along with the slaves of the Dutch colonies, including <tei-placeName ref="#SU" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Surinam</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName ref="#CU" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Curaçao</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName ref="#STE" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Saint-Eustache</tei-placeName> and <tei-placeName ref="#SAB" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Saba</tei-placeName> estimated at a total of around 100 million francs, would bring the indemnity claimed to nearly two billion francs for Europe alone.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">It cannot be denied that slavery developed under the patronage of government; however, the emancipation of blacks should not become a source of profit for the colonists at the expense of the metropolises. If such a sum were granted, the colonists would simultaneously be reimbursed for their advances while continuing to benefit from the labor they initially sought to secure by acquiring slaves.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">From an economic standpoint, colonial questions are hardly easier to resolve, although the excellent considerations of M. de Montvéran regarding the development of the colony of Cuba, freed from the monopolies of the mother country, suggest what the solution should be.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Indeed, the colonies annually produce 648,000,000 kilograms of sugar and 85,000,000 kilograms of coffee; they receive in exchange roughly 500,000,000 francs worth of consumer goods. This trade, amounting to one billion francs and employing a fleet of 600,000 tons, nearly 5,000 ships manned by 36,000 to 40,000 sailors, is undoubtedly an impressive example of commercial development. But under what conditions does it occur?</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">The metropolises initially consumed little in the way of colonial goods; they found nothing simpler than to grant each colony a monopoly on their supply while reserving for themselves the monopoly on their consumption. What has resulted from this arrangement? The growth in the consumption of colonial goods was extremely rapid in European countries, and soon it <tei-pb n="46" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/> was no longer aligned with the production resources of the colonies. Thus, on one hand, the colonies complained that the metropolises made them pay dearly for goods they could have procured more cheaply from other nations; on the other hand, the metropolises demanded the free importation of goods that the colonies were only supplying at an extremely high cost. The natural solution was commercial freedom for both; however, as the necessity of meeting an ever-growing consumption had placed the colonies in completely abnormal production conditions, and as their goods could only find a market within the metropolis, this freedom became the signal of their ruin.</tei-p>
         </tei-div>
         <tei-div data-origname="div">
            <tei-head data-origname="head">BIBLIOGRAPHY.</tei-head>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">The <tei-bibl type="periodical" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type"><tei-title ref="#RdC" data-origname="title" data-origatts="ref">Revue des Colonies</tei-title></tei-bibl> will not remain indifferent to the intellectual movement of the time and will keep a faithful record of all publications it considers of some interest to the cause of liberty and universal civilization.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Among recently published works, <tei-bibl type="monogr" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type">les Paroles d'un Croyant</tei-bibl>, de <tei-persName ref="#DLM" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">M. de La Mennais</tei-persName> deserves particular attention. Never has a book had such an impact, and this is understandable: <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Paroles d'un Croyant</tei-emph> is not only written in the high and resolute style familiar to M. de La Mennais; it touches upon all the pressing questions that today divide the world that is ending from the world that is beginning. It troubles and stirs the souls that slumber in complacency with the present, and it encourages and consoles those who work providentially for the future. This book has particularly sown consternation and fear among the ranks of the champions of the past.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Although a priest, M. de La Mennais has had the distinction of being quasi-excommunicated by the Pope. His book has been entirely condemned, and in very harsh and fanatical terms, which are an evident sign that the true Christian spirit, always rare among popes, has entirely departed from the Holy See, which, like all old institutions, is also crumbling.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">To give an idea of the eloquent writer's style, we will quote here the following two beautiful passages, admirable in every respect, which one might call the parable<tei-emph data-origname="emph"> </tei-emph>of<tei-emph data-origname="emph"> </tei-emph>ASSOCIATION and the parable OF LIBERTY.</tei-p>
               <tei-pb n="47" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">- When a tree stands alone, it is battered by the winds and stripped of its leaves; and its branches, instead of rising, droop as if they seek the earth. When a plant is alone, finding no shelter against the heat of the sun, it languishes, withers, and dies. When man is alone, the wind of power bends him toward the ground, and the heat of the greed of the great of this world absorbs the sap that nourishes him. Be not, therefore, like the tree and the plant that stand alone; but unite with one another, support one another, and shelter one another. While you remain divided, and each thinks only of himself, you can expect nothing but suffering, misfortune, and oppression. What is weaker than the sparrow and more defenseless than the swallow? Yet, when the bird of prey appears, the swallows and sparrows manage to drive it away by gathering around it and chasing it together. Take example from the sparrow and the swallow. He who separates from his brothers is followed by fear when he walks, sits beside him when he rests, and does not leave him even during his sleep. Therefore, if someone asks you: How many are you? answer: We are one, for our brothers are us, and we are our brothers.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">God has made neither small nor great, neither masters nor slaves, neither kings nor subjects; He has made all men equal. But among men, some possess more strength of body, mind, or will, and it is those who seek to subjugate others when pride or greed smothers the love of their brothers within them. And God knew it would be so, and that is why He commanded men to love one another, so that they might be united and the weak might not fall under the oppression of the strong. For he who is stronger than one will be less strong than two, and he who is stronger than two will be less strong than four; and thus, the weak will fear nothing when, loving one another, they are truly united.</tei-p>
               <tei-pb n="48" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/>
            
            <tei-p data-origname="p">A man was traveling through the mountains, and he came to a place where a large boulder, having rolled onto the path, blocked it entirely, and off the path, there was no way through, neither to the left nor to the right.  </tei-p>
            
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Now, this man, seeing that he could not continue his journey because of the boulder, tried to move it to make himself a passage. He exhausted himself with this task, and all his efforts were in vain. Seeing this, he sat down full of sadness and said: "What will become of me when night falls and finds me in this solitude, without shelter, without any defense, at the hour when wild beasts come out to seek their prey?"  </tei-p>
            
            <tei-p data-origname="p">And as he was absorbed in this thought, another traveler came along, and he too tried to do what the first had done, but found himself equally unable to move the boulder. He sat down in silence and lowered his head.  </tei-p>
            
            <tei-p data-origname="p">After him, several others arrived, and none could move the boulder, and they all felt great fear. At last, one of them said to the others: "My brothers, let us pray to our Father who is in heaven; perhaps He will have pity on us in this distress."  </tei-p>
            
            <tei-p data-origname="p">And these words were heeded, and they prayed earnestly to the Father who is in heaven.  </tei-p>
            
            <tei-p data-origname="p">And when they had prayed, the one who had said, "Let us pray," spoke again: "My brothers, what none of us could do alone, who knows if we might not accomplish it all together?"  </tei-p>
            
            <tei-p data-origname="p">And they rose, and all together they pushed the boulder, and the boulder gave way, and they continued on their journey in peace.  </tei-p>
            
            <tei-p data-origname="p">The traveler is man, the journey is life, and the boulder is the miseries he encounters at every step on his path. No man can lift this boulder alone, but God has measured its weight so that it never halts those who travel together.  </tei-p>
            
            <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">II.</tei-emph></tei-p>
            
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Do not let yourselves be deceived by empty words. Many will seek to persuade you that you are truly free because they have written the word LIBERTY on a piece of paper and posted it at every street corner.  </tei-p>
            
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Liberty is not a poster to be read at the corner of the street; it <tei-pb n="49" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/> is a living power felt within and around oneself, the protective spirit of the domestic hearth, the guarantor of social rights, and the foremost of those rights.  </tei-p>
            
            <tei-p data-origname="p">The oppressor who cloaks himself in its name is the worst of oppressors; he combines falsehood with tyranny and profanation with injustice: for the name LIBERTY is sacred.  </tei-p>
            
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Beware, then, of those who cry, "Liberty, liberty," and destroy it by their deeds. </tei-p>
            
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Do you choose those who govern you, who command you to do this and not do that, who levy taxes on your goods, your industry, your labor? And if it is not you, how are you free?</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">The birds of the sky and even the insects gather together to achieve collectively what none of them could accomplish alone. Can you assemble to deliberate together on your interests, to defend your rights, to seek some relief from your sufferings? And if you cannot, how are you free?</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Can you move from one place to another without permission, enjoy the fruits of the earth and the products of your labor, dip your finger in the sea's water, and let a drop fall into the humble earthen pot where your food cooks, without risking a fine or being dragged to prison? And if you cannot, how are you free?</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Can you, as you lie down at night, be certain that no one will come during your sleep to search the most private corners of your home, tear you from your family, and throw you into a dungeon because power, in its fear, has grown suspicious of you? And if you cannot, how are you free?</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Liberty will shine upon you when, through courage and perseverance, you have freed yourselves from all these servitudes.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Liberty will shine upon you when you say deep within your soul: <tei-emph data-origname="emph">We want to be free,</tei-emph> when you are ready to sacrifice everything and endure all to achieve it.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">Liberty will shine upon you when, at the foot of the cross on which Christ died for you, you swear to die for one another.</tei-p>
            <tei-p data-origname="p">IMPRIMERIE D'HERHAN, 580, RUE SAINT-DENIS</tei-p>
            
         </tei-div>

    <tei-listPerson data-origname="listPerson">
        <tei-person xml:id="ADA" id="ADA" data-origname="person" data-origatts="xml:id">
            <tei-persName xml:lang="en" lang="en" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">John Adams</tei-persName>
            <tei-persName xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">John Adams</tei-persName>
            <tei-birth data-origname="birth">1735</tei-birth>
            <tei-death data-origname="death">1826</tei-death>
            <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="Person" resp="#masha #michaël" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">John Adams stands out among the first American presidents as a northerner who was never an enslaver. In the immediate aftermath of the American Revolution, he opposed efforts to implement large-scale emancipation in his home state of Massachusetts, but, as primary author of the state’s constitution, which included a Declaration of Rights (written after Adams served as Envoy to France), Adams has long been associated with the state’s de facto abolition in 1780. It was only after the 1781 cases of Mum Bett and Quok Walker, enslaved people who cited the language of the constitution in suing for their freedom, that the document, which does not explicitly prohibit slavery, took on this accepted meaning. </tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">John Adams’s presidency is notably marked by the establishment of trade relations with Haiti, which was then in conflict with France.  These political positions, in combination with an 1801 letter in which he expresses “abhorrence” to the institution of slavery, claiming to have always employed free men at significant personal expense, have contributed to Adams’ enduring legacy as a committed abolitionist. Recently, historians have called attention to the ways in which his positions were more in line with contemporaries, noting both that, with regard to Haiti, agreement to continue commerce is hardly a statement of ideological sympathy, and that any actual belief in the principle of equality was never public or explicit.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                </tei-p>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl" data-empty=""/>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Rossignol, Marie-Jeanne and Michaël Roy, with Marlene L. Daut and Cécile Roudeau, eds.  <tei-title data-origname="title">Anthologie de la pensée noire. États-Unis et Haïti (xviiie-xixe siècles)</tei-title>  . Marseille: Hors d’atteinte, 2023.</tei-bibl>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">McCullough, David.  <tei-title data-origname="title">John Adams</tei-title>  . New York: Simon & Schuster, 2001.</tei-bibl>
            </tei-note>
            <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="Person" resp="#masha #michaël" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">John Adams est originaire du Nord des États-Unis et n’a jamais possédé d’esclaves, ce qui le distingue des premiers présidents américains. Bien qu’opposé à l’émancipation générale des esclaves dans son État natal du Massachusetts après la Révolution, il rédige pour le jeune État une constitution qui comprend une Déclaration des droits (il rentre alors d’une mission diplomatique en France) et œuvre de fait à la disparition progressive de l’esclavage dans le Massachusetts. Dans les années qui suivent l’adoption de la constitution en 1780, des personnes esclavisées telles que Mum Bett et Quok Walker n'hésitent pas à invoquer ce document pour poursuivre leur maître et réclamer leur liberté devant les tribunaux.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Le mandat de John Adams est notamment marqué par l’établissement de relations commerciales avec Haïti, alors en conflit avec la France. Ses prises de position politiques, ainsi qu’une lettre de 1801 dans laquelle il exprime sa « détestation » de l’esclavage et affirme avoir toujours employé des hommes libres, même lorsque le coût de leur travail était élevé, ont largement contribué à forger sa réputation d’abolitionniste engagé.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Cette image a toutefois été nuancée par l’historiographie récente, qui souligne la proximité d’Adams avec ses contemporains sur la question de l’esclavage. Le maintien des échanges avec Haïti, par exemple, ne traduit pas nécessairement une sympathie à l’égard de l’indépendance haïtienne, et Adams ne s’est jamais publiquement ni explicitement exprimé en faveur de l’égalité raciale.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                </tei-p>
            </tei-note>
        </tei-person>
        <tei-person xml:id="JEF" id="JEF" data-origname="person" data-origatts="xml:id">
            <tei-persName xml:lang="en" lang="en" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Thomas Jefferson</tei-persName>
            <tei-persName xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Thomas Jefferson</tei-persName>
            <tei-birth data-origname="birth">1743</tei-birth>
            <tei-death data-origname="death">1826</tei-death>
            <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="Person" resp="#michaël #masha" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">For the period of his life encompassing his time as president, the value of Thomas Jefferson’s personal estate primarily lay in the hundreds of enslaved people laboring at his plantation and mansion, Monticello. Deeply in debt through the end of his life, Jefferson manumitted very few people despite expressing abhorrence to the institution on numerous occasions.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">His public comments on slavery, whether in the colonial context of <tei-emph data-origname="emph">A Summary View of the Rights of British America</tei-emph> (1774) or in the early republic, as in <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Notes on the State of Virginia</tei-emph> (1785), his most well-known commentary on the subject, stress the risks and complications of any potential abolition while stopping short of defending the practice outright. In an early draft of the Declaration of Independence, Jefferson blames George III for forcefully maintaining the slave trade in North America, though this condemnation is less a matter of moral outrage than fear of organized rebellion. Jefferson received a copy of <tei-emph data-origname="emph">De la littérature des Nègres</tei-emph> (1808), a work excerpted in numerous issues of the Revue des Colonies, directly from Abbé Grégoire. His response actually criticizes the work, whose arguments for equal humanity depend on the intellectual accomplishments of Black people, for implying that rights should be bound to talent. For his own part, Jefferson was notably dismissive of the intellectual talents of Benjamin Banneker, the free-born Black polymath who wrote to him in 1791 demanding (unsuccessfully) that he act according to his professed principles and Phillis Wheatley, the enslaved poet whose work was widely circulated on both sides of the Atlantic.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">In <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Notes</tei-emph>, published in France (while Jefferson was serving as minister to the court of Louis XVI) as a response to questions posed to the Continental Congress by delegate François Barbé-Marbois, Jefferson argues that any large-scale emancipation project would destabilize the young state by plunging it into violent racial conflict. As an alternative, he takes up the nascent cause of colonization, a position roundly criticized by later American abolitionists, most notably David Walker in his <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Appeal</tei-emph> (1829). At this time, Jefferson was living with Sally Hemings, an enslaved woman of mixed race and his deceased wife’s half-sister. This sexual relationship, to which Hemings would have had no meaningful way of consenting, was believed to have lasted four decades, producing several children. Hemings experienced the conditions of legal freedom for the first time while in France and returned to Virginia only on the condition that Jefferson would emancipate their children upon their reaching adulthood.</tei-p>
            </tei-note>
            <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="Person" resp="#michaël #masha" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Durant la période de sa vie correspondant à son mandat présidentiel, le patrimoine de Thomas Jefferson est essentiellement constitué des centaines d’esclaves qui travaillent pour lui dans sa plantation et sa résidence de Monticello. Lourdement endetté, Jefferson émancipe très peu de personnes au cours de sa vie, et ce alors même qu’il exprime à de nombreuses reprises des positions critiques sur l’esclavage.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Jefferson évoque la question de l’esclavage dans plusieurs de ses écrits, en particulier <tei-emph data-origname="emph">A Summary View of the Rights of British America</tei-emph> (1774) et <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Notes on the State of Virginia</tei-emph> (1785), son texte le plus connu. S’il ne défend pas l’institution esclavagiste, il insiste cependant sur les risques et les difficultés de son abolition éventuelle. Dans une première version de la Déclaration d’indépendance, Jefferson reproche à George III d’avoir maintenu la traite en Amérique du Nord, ce qui traduit moins une indignation morale que la crainte de voir les esclaves se soulever. Lorsque l’abbé Grégoire publie <tei-emph data-origname="emph">De la littérature des nègres</tei-emph> en 1808, dont de nombreux extraits sont reproduits dans la Revue des Colonies, il fait parvenir un exemplaire à Jefferson. Dans sa réponse à Grégoire, Jefferson critique l’ouvrage, qui, en s’appuyant sur les accomplissements intellectuels des personnes noires pour défendre l’égalité humaine, suggère que les droits humains devraient être conditionnés au talent.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">En outre, Jefferson fait preuve de condescendance envers Benjamin Banneker, mathématicien noir né libre, qui lui adresse une lettre en 1791 l’exhortant (sans succès) à agir en cohérence avec ses principes égalitaires, ainsi qu’envers Phillis Wheatley, poétesse esclavisée dont les œuvres sont largement diffusées des deux côtés de l’Atlantique.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Dans <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Notes on the State of Virginia</tei-emph>, publié en réponse aux questions posées au Congrès continental par François Barbé-Marbois alors que Jefferson occupe le poste de ministre plénipotentiaire des États-Unis à la cour de Louis XVI, il soutient qu’un projet d’émancipation à grande échelle risquerait de déstabiliser la nation naissante en provoquant des conflits raciaux violents. Jefferson choisit plutôt d’adhérer à la cause dite de la colonisation – c’est-à-dire l’expatriation des plus ou moins contrainte des Africains-Américains libres –, un projet que les abolitionnistes américains critiqueront fermement par la suite, à l’instar de David Walker dans <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Appeal to the Colored Citizens of the World</tei-emph> (1829).</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">À la fin des années 1780, Jefferson vit en concubinage avec Sally Hemings, femme de couleur esclavisée et demi-sœur de sa défunte épouse. Cette relation, à laquelle Hemings ne pouvait consentir, aurait duré près de quarante ans et a généré une descendance. Hemings fait pour la première fois l’expérience de la liberté lorsqu’elle est en France et n’accepte de retourner en Virginie qu’à la condition que Jefferson s’engage à affranchir leurs enfants à leur majorité.</tei-p>

        <tei-person xml:id="WAS" id="WAS" data-origname="person" data-origatts="xml:id">
            <tei-persName xml:lang="en" lang="en" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">George Washington </tei-persName>
            <tei-persName xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">George Washington</tei-persName>
            <tei-birth data-origname="birth">1732</tei-birth>
            <tei-death data-origname="death">1799</tei-death>
            <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="Person" resp="#michaël #masha" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Unlike fellow architects of the early American republic, George Washington did not spend any time in Europe or read in French, nor, in seeking French support for American independence, did he explicitly draw logical connections between independence and emancipation. During the Revolution, Washington, conceding to the demands of war after initial reluctance, led an integrated Continental Army, including free and enslaved men of color. As President, however, Washington carefully avoided maintaining consistent residence in Philadelphia, the nation’s first capital, to avoid being subject to Pennsylvania’s gradual abolition act of 1780.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Washington was a third-generation enslaver, who, at the time of his death in 1799, held personal claim to 123 enslaved people, while his Virginia home and plantation, Mount Vernon, benefited from the labor of over 300 in total, the remainder being temporary laborers or enslaved people inherited from the estate of his wife’s first husband. In his will, published widely in U.S. papers, he stipulated emancipation for those in his personal estate upon Martha Washington’s death, suggesting a moral stance while notably deferring financial loss to his inheritors. Meanwhile, through the final years of his life, he continued a relentless pursuit of Ona Judge, a young enslaved woman who had fled Mount Vernon for New Hampshire. In seeking to recover her, he refused her willing return on the condition of being freed after his and Martha’s deaths, and only hesitated to enforce the Fugitive Slave Act of 1793 for fear of drawing negative publicity to the case and galvanizing northern abolitionists.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Historians continue to debate Washington’s personal degree of comfort with or distaste for the institution of slavery, and whether he harbored any conviction to endorse gradual abolition.  François Furstenberg has drawn attention to his bound collection of antislavery tracts from American and European sources while noting that several of these works were never opened and his sentiments on the matter were restricted to private correspondence.</tei-p>

                </tei-p>

            </tei-note>
            <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="Person" resp="#michaël #masha" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Contrairement à d'autres figures fondatrices de la jeune République américaine, George Washington n’a jamais séjourné en France ni entretenu de relations directes avec les grands penseurs français de la fin du XVIIIe siècle. Dans sa quête de soutien français pour l’indépendance américaine, il ne lie pas explicitement cette cause à celle de l’émancipation. Pendant la Révolution, Washington, contraint par les impératifs de la guerre,dirige une armée non ségréguée, qui inclut des hommes de couleur libres et asservis. En tant que président, Washington s’est toutefois soigneusement abstenu de résider de manière prolongée à Philadelphie, première capitale du pays, afin d’éviter d’être soumis à la loi d’abolition graduelle de l’esclavage adoptée par la Pennsylvanie en 1780.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Issu d’une famille d’esclavagistes vieille de trois générations, Washington possède à sa mort, en 1799, quelque 123 personnes esclavisées. En tout, plus de 300 personnes travaillent dans sa plantation de Mount Vernon, en Virginie, parmi lesquelles des travailleurs temporaires et des esclaves hérités du premier mariage de sa femme, Martha. Dans son testament, largement diffusé dans la presse américaine, Washington prévoit que ses esclaves seront émancipés à la mort de son épouse, ce qui lui permet d’afficher une posture morale tout en reportant les pertes financières sur ses héritiers. Parallèlement, durant les dernières années de sa vie, il poursuit sans relâche Ona Judge, une jeune femme asservie qui s’est enfuie de Mount Vernon et a gagné le New Hampshire. Lorsque celle-ci propose de revenir à la condition que sa liberté lui soit accordée après la mort de George et Martha, Washington refuse ; de même, il hésite à se saisir de la loi sur les esclaves fugitifs de 1793, craignant que cela n’attire l’attention et ne galvanise les abolitionnistes du Nord.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Les historiens continuent de débattre de la position plus ou moins critique de Washington sur l’esclavage et de son degré d’adhésion au projet d’une abolition graduelle de l’institution. François Furstenberg s’est notamment intéressé à sa collection de livres, qui comprend plusieurs brochures abolitionnistes publiées en Europe et en Amérique du Nord. Il note cependant que certains de ces volumes n’ont jamais été ouverts, et que les réflexions de Washington sur la question restent cantonnées à sa correspondance privée.</tei-p>

                </tei-p>
            </tei-note>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">Mr. Adolphe Ambroise Alexandre Gatine (1805–1864) was a lawyer at the Council of State and the Court of Cassation and a French abolitionist. From the 1830s, he distinguished himself by defending free people of color (e.g., the Louisy and Léonarde cases, the Grande-Anse case, and the Virginie case) as well as advocating for the rights of enslaved individuals claiming their freedom. In 1848, he was appointed General Commissioner of Guadeloupe, where he arrived on June 5th carrying the abolition decree dated April 27, 1848. However, abolition had already been proclaimed locally on May 27th.</tei-p>
            </tei-note>
            <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="Person" resp="#jessica" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Adolphe Ambroise Alexandre Gatine (1805-1864), est un avocat du Conseil d'État et de la Cour de cassation et un abolitionniste français. Il s’illustre, dès les années 1830, dans la défense des libres de couleur (Affaires Louisy et Léonarde, affaire de la Grande-Anse, affaire Virginie) mais également dans la défense des intérêts des esclaves revendiquant leur liberté. En 1848, il est désigné commissaire général de la Guadeloupe où il débarque le 5 juin avec le décret d'abolition du 27 avril 1848. L'abolition avait néanmoins déjà été proclamée depuis le 27 mai.</tei-p>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">Olaudah Equiano was among the most prominent British abolitionists of the late eighteenth century. Born around 1745, he was sold as a child to the British captain Michael Pascal, who gave him the name Gustavas Vassa, which remained his legal name for the remainder of his life. Equiano served in the British Navy during the Seven Years’ War and in 1766, he purchased his freedom from the American merchant Robert King.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">As a free man in London in the 1780s, Equiano became more active in the abolitionist movement, notably working with Granville Sharp to bring public attention to the 1781 Zong massacre, in which more than 130 enslaved people were thrown overboard to their deaths while crossing the Atlantic. In 1789, Equiano published his autobiography (his first public use of the name Olaudah Equiano), <tei-title data-origname="title">The Interesting Narrative of the Life of Olaudah Equiano</tei-title>, or Gustavus Vassa, the African, which was an instant success in Britain and abroad, becoming the standard for the genre of the slave narrative.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">The feature on Equiano that appears in the Revue is taken directly from <tei-title data-origname="title">Abbé Grégoire’s De la littérature des nègres</tei-title> (1808) a survey of writing by Black authors through the turn of the nineteenth century. In the included passage, Grégoire paraphrases the accounts of Equiano’s early childhood in <tei-title data-origname="title">The Interesting Narrative</tei-title>. These passages reflect a consistent point of emphasis in the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> itself, that the Euopean slave trade corrupts otherwise functional and sophisticated cultures. Later in <tei-title data-origname="title">The Interesting Narrative</tei-title>, Equiano makes a plea for the end of the slave trade in the British Empire that the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> echoes regularly: that free trade with the African continent would ultimately be more profitable to the nations that supposedly benefit from slave economies.</tei-p>

                <tei-p data-origname="p">Born in 1802 to Marie-Louise Elisabeth Labouret and Thomas-Alexandre Dumas Davy de la Pailleterie, a Revolutionary War general from Saint-Domingue, Alexandre Dumas (also known as Alexandre Dumas père) was among the most popular French playwrights and novelists of the nineteenth century. Dumas received early education in his native Villers-Cotterets from Abbé Grégoire, who ran a local school. By the 1830’s, Dumas was a successful dramatist and a leading figure in the Romantic movement, though he was not favored by contemporary critics. Over the course of the twentieth century, Dumas’ canonical status would be solidified, culminating with the transfer of his remains to the Pantheon in 2002.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Dumas’ Haitian ancestry, and accordingly, his race were regular subjects of caricature and malicious insinuation in his time, thus Dumas rarely explicitly identified himself as a person of color or took up questions of race and slavery in his writing. One notable exception is the 1843 novel <tei-title data-origname="title">Georges</tei-title>, which depicts a slave uprising in Isle de France (Mauritius), and in its narrative and rhetoric appears to reflect Dumas’ engagement with the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue des Colonies</tei-title>.</tei-p>

            <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="Person" resp="#masha" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">

                    <tei-graphic url="dumas_74784dd0f5.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/>
                    <tei-figDesc data-origname="figDesc">Portrait de Alexandre Dumas</tei-figDesc>
                </tei-figure>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Born in 1802 to Marie-Louise Elisabeth Labouret and Thomas-Alexandre Dumas Davy de la Pailleterie, a Revolutionary War general from Saint-Domingue, Alexandre Dumas (also known as Alexandre Dumas père) was among the most popular French playwrights and novelists of the nineteenth century. Dumas received early education in his native Villers-Cotterets from Abbé Grégoire, who ran a local school. By the 1830’s, Dumas was a successful dramatist and a leading figure in the Romantic movement, though he was not favored by contemporary critics. Over the course of the twentieth century, Dumas’ canonical status would be solidified, culminating with the transfer of his remains to the Pantheon in 2002.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Dumas’ Haitian ancestry, and accordingly, his race were regular subjects of caricature and malicious insinuation in his time, thus Dumas rarely explicitly identified himself as a person of color or took up questions of race and slavery in his writing. One notable exception is the 1843 novel <tei-title data-origname="title">Georges</tei-title>, which depicts a slave uprising in Isle de France (Mauritius), and in its narrative and rhetoric appears to reflect Dumas’ engagement with the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue des Colonies</tei-title>.</tei-p>

Presses universitaires de Caen, 2021.</tei-bibl>
